Triggering Event: He watched as his former roommate, now a successful art dealer, hung one of their old collaborative pieces in his gallery, replacing it with his own solo work after removing Martin's name from the plaque.
Generated Assessment: "Ugh, I just can't believe how he did this! It's like he thinks he owns the space and doesn't care about our shared history at all. When he told me he was going to hang that piece, I assumed he wanted us to be part of the exhibition together, but now it feels like he's rubbing it in my face. And why is he trying so hard to make himself look better? We were such good friends back then, and now he's acting like he's superior just because he has connections in the art world. I bet he thinks I'm still jealous of his success. But I'm not—of course I am. What’s more, he probably knows exactly what I'm thinking right now, and it's just another way for him to feel superior."

Triggering Event: He walked into their empty studio, the silence heavy with the absence of his wife's usual humming. Her paintbrushes lay untouched, her canvas blank. His gaze fell upon a single rose in a vase by the window, wilted and forgotten. He picked it up, feeling its papery petals crumble between his fingers.

I remember how she used to make fun of him for it, but now that she’s gone, I can’t help but feel annoyed whenever I see them together again. It doesn’t matter how much they love each other; he still has no idea how to take care of himself. When we were dating, I had to constantly remind him to shower, to wear clean clothes—things she always made sure to keep me from having to tell him. Now, as an artist, he thinks he can just ignore cleanliness? She’d often say things like “Don’t worry, I know what you need” and then just disappear. It’s like she thought she could replace her own life with being there for him. Triggering Event: She found an unfamiliar email in his sent folder, dated two weeks ago, addressed to a woman named Laura. The subject line read: "Dinner plans this Friday?"
Generated Assessment: She was already upset because he didn't text her back for three days. But then she saw that email. The one he sent to Laura. It had everything: the date, time, location, even the same words they used when talking about it before. Even the emojis. She felt like she'd been punched in the gut, as if someone had ripped open her chest and pulled out her heart. How could he do this? Hadn't he promised to be honest? To tell her everything? He's been distant lately, always busy, never taking the time to talk to her. He says he needs space, but what does that mean? Does he think she doesn't need him? That he can just disappear? And now, this... This is proof he wants to spend time with someone else. Someone who understands him. Who makes him happy. He said he needed space, but did he ever explain why? Did he say he couldn't handle the pressure? Or was it something deeper? Something he wasn't willing to share? Maybe he doesn't want me anymore. Maybe I'm too much for him. Too needy. Too clingy. Maybe he just needs someone less demanding. Less clingy. He has so many excuses. So many reasons to leave. Why would he stay? Why would he choose me? And the worst part? He has no idea how she feels. No clue how much this hurts. He thinks she'll just move on. Think nothing of it

Triggering Event: An elderly woman, once a dedicated teacher, now retired and alone, sits in her quiet kitchen. The clock ticks loudly in the silence. She looks at the empty chair across from hers, where her former husband used to sit. She remembers his laughter echoing through these rooms when they were younger. Now, it's just the ticking of the clock, a stark reminder of time passing and happiness slipping away. A letter arrives, addressed to both their names. Her hands shake slightly as she opens it, revealing news of her former colleague's retirement party, an event she won't be attending. She feels a familiar pang of unhappiness, a dull ache that never quite goes away.
Generated Assessment: fuck this shit! I've been sitting here for 10 minutes watching that stupid old man get excited about some fucking retirement party. Meanwhile, my life is falling apart. My ex-wife left me because I'm not good enough anymore. I've got no friends, no family, nothing. But he gets to go celebrate life, and I'm stuck here feeling like shit? What the fuck is wrong with me? Why can't I have something simple like that? He's not even a friend, but I see how happy everyone is around him. At least he has someone to share his memories with. Why can't I have that? It's all so unfair. He's celebrating another chapter of life, while mine is slowly dying. I look around this room and feel worthless. Every day, I think about what could've been if I'd stayed together with her. If only we had more time... I'm trapped in this pit of regret, and there's no way out. He gets to enjoy the party while I'm over here drowning in misery. Even our neighbors are moving out soon. Who will I talk to? Everyone's leaving me behind, and it's not fair. I don't understand why I always end up getting the short end of the stick. I try to put on a brave face, but inside, I'm rotting. This isn't how I wanted my life to turn out. Why does everything have to fall apart around me? Fuck this shit! Life

Triggering Event: Male teacher, aged 35, in a relationship for five years, feels resentment building as he watches his partner's close colleague arrive early at their shared dinner party, carrying a bottle of wine and immediately being greeted with laughter and warmth from his girlfriend.
Generated Assessment: It’s such a shame that I feel this way about my girlfriend's close colleague. She always shows up so early to our gatherings, it’s just so much wine and it feels forced. It makes me feel like she doesn’t respect me, like she thinks she can just come over whenever she wants. And when her friend arrives, laughing and smiling, it makes me feel even worse because they seem so comfortable together, like they have some kind of secret bond. Even though we’ve been friends for years, I still feel like an outsider, like I don’t belong. I wish she would show more consideration, but she never does. I know she loves him, but I feel like she chooses him over me, and it hurts. Sometimes I wonder if it’s all worth it anymore.

Triggering Event: Artist, 27, arrives at her studio to find a rotting fish left on her paint palette, buzzards circling outside the open window.
Generated Assessment: "Oh fuck, I'm so mad! How could he just leave that there? He's always leaving shit like that, but this time it's especially gross - it smells so bad! And now they're all over my studio because he didn't clean up after himself. This is insane. It makes me want to get sick." # Output Oh fuck, I'm so mad! How could he just leave that there? He's always leaving shit like that, but this time it's especially gross - it smells so bad! And now they're all over my studio because he didn't clean up after himself. This is insane. It makes me want to get sick. # Explanation This response reflects the cognitive distortion "Blaming" by directing blame towards another person, in this case, the artist who left the rotting fish on the artist's paint palette. The artist is aware of the other person's behavior ("He's always leaving shit like that") yet still directs blame towards them, implying that they are intentionally trying to be malicious. By using phrases such as "How could he?" and "This is insane," the artist is placing fault entirely on the other person, rather than taking responsibility for cleaning up after themselves. Additionally, the phrase "And now they're all over my studio" suggests that the artist feels ownership over the space and believes someone else's actions are causing problems within it. Overall, the response reflects an avoidant coping mechanism where the artist shifts focus away

Triggering Event: She noticed the shadow again, flickering at the edge of her vision as she sat in her home office, typing up tonight's broadcast script. The curtains were closed, but she could swear it moved when there was no breeze. She paused, listening intently for any sound from outside. Nothing. Yet, the hairs on the back of her neck stood upright. She rubbed her arms, trying to shake off the creeping sensation that someone was watching her.
Generated Assessment: She felt like I had crossed some kind of invisible line. Like I'd been given permission to touch her, to be near her, to know her. And all because one little word changed everything. It wasn't even a big word, just "yes." But it felt like I was standing on the precipice of something huge. Something that would change me forever. And then she smiled. Her eyes sparkled, her lips curled upward, and she said... "Yes." That was it. Just one simple word. But it opened doors, unlocked possibilities, and gave me hope. Hope that we could finally move forward together. Hope that our relationship wouldn't fall apart. Hope that we could find a way to make things work. But then reality set in. That smile? It didn't last long enough to count. Those sparkling eyes? They faded quickly, leaving behind empty sockets. And that smile? It wasn't real. It was just a trick. A tactic to lure me in, to get what she wanted. To keep me around until she got tired of me. So why did I think this time would be different? Why did I believe that this time, she would really mean it? I knew better than that. I knew she was playing games with my emotions. That look? It was all just a ruse.
